REGISTER LOGIN

Welcome

The virtual speaker training will provide you with the skills needed to deliver core amyloidosis and tafamidis
content. Additionally, it will educate you on powerful and effective means of communicating key messages
both in person and via virtual delivery and will establish a platform for ongoing learning and networking
beyond the live events.

Denis Keohane, Pfizer

Dr Esther González-López

Hospital Puerta de Hierro Majadahonda, Madrid, Spain

Dr Esther González López currently works as a Consultant Cardiologist at Hospital Puerta de Hierro Majadahonda in Madrid, Spain. She completed her initial training as a specialist in cardiology at Hospital Puerta de Hierro Majadahonda, and, during this period, became interested in the field of cardiomyopathies and cardiac imaging. Dr González López completed her PhD on imaging techniques in transthyretin cardiac amyloidosis and part of her thesis, assessing the prevalence of wild-type transthyretin cardiac amyloidosis in patients with heart failure and preserved ejection fraction, was published in European Heart Journal in 2015. She has also participated in basic amyloid research at Centro Nacional de Investigaciones Cardiovasculares (CNIC) in Madrid.

Following her stays at the Heart Hospital in London, UK, and at the Cardiac Amyloidosis Program at Brigham and Women’s Hospital in Boston, MA, USA, Dr González López went on to work at the National Amyloidosis Centre (NAC) in London. In January 2019, she returned to Hospital Puerta de Hierro Majadahonda, with a shared dedication between the cardiac imaging unit and the Inherited Cardiac Diseases Unit, national reference unit. She continues doing clinical research on transthyretin cardiac amyloidosis, being principal investigator of national and competitive projects as well as collaborating with other international amyloidosis groups, in addition of being part of the European Amyloid Proteomics Working Group.

Prof. Stefano Perlini

Department of Internal Medicine, University of Pavia, Pavia, Italy

Prof. Stefano Perlini served as Cardiologist in the Division of Cardiology of the IRCCS “Ospedale Maggiore di Milano” from 1991 to 1998, when he moved to the University of Pavia. He was appointed as Full Professor of Internal Medicine in 2019.
Since 2001 he is Consultant Cardiologist of the Center for the Study of Systemic Amyloidosis of the IRCCS San Matteo Foundation, University of Pavia. Since 2019 he is the Director of the Emergency Medicine Department. His research training included several experiences overseas (summer 1985: Cardiac Department, Brompton Hospital, London, UK; 1990-1991: Department of Cardiovascular Medicine and Nuffield Department of Anaesthesiology, University of Oxford, UK; 1995-1996: Research Fellow, Department of Cardiology, University of Massachusetts Medical Center, Worcester, MA, USA). He obtained several Research Fellowships and Prizes (1988-1990: IRCCS Policlinico “San Matteo” Fellowship; 1990-1991: Bristol-Myers Squibb Fellowship Award; 1993: “Young Investigator Award” of the Italian Society of Cardiology; 1995: “Salvatore Campus” Fellowship of the Italian Society of Arterial Hypertension; 1999: Prize for the Best Poster presented at the Annual Meeting of the Italian Society of Arterial Hypertension). He is a member of several Scientific Societies, member of the Editorial Board of The Journal of Hypertension and of the European Journal of Clinical Investigation, reviewer for several journals (Circulation, Hypertension, Cardiovascular Research, Journal of Hypertension, European Journal of Cardiology, British Medical Journal, Amyloid, Lancet). He is co-author of 200 full papers (IF = 998), of more than 500 abstracts presented at international meetings and 10 book chapters.

The main research interest is focused on the study of the mechanisms underlying systolic and diastolic dysfunction evident in myocardial hypertrophy and in different cardiomyopathies, in both the clinical and the experimental setting. A special interest is devoted to diagnosis and treatment of cardiac amyloidosis. He is also interested in the application of new teaching methodologies, such as the use of simulation as a training tool in medicine, to develop both clinical skills (such as cardiac auscultation) and the capability of dealing with clinical cases.

Dr. Fabio Barroso
